location.city_name: Signing Babies with Lee Ann Steyns

social_posts.post_text:
➡️ To sign NO in American Sign Language, tap index and middle fingers down to the thumb. This sign means business, think of literally shutting something down as you close your fingers down to your thumb.

Signing NO can help you reply to a question or confirm when you want things to stop. 🛑

You can add this sign to daily conversations when NO makes sense -and remember to stick to your guns so there’s no confusion. We always want clear context when we use signs. That way, your little one will come to understand what NO means and expect you to follow up after you say and sign it. 💥

This creates clear, understandable, consistent communication that you’re building as a family. ✔️

When do you say NO to your baby? 
- - - - - - - - - - - - -

social_posts.post_text:
Your POV could look like smiles and signs like this! 

It’s not tricky at all. 

Instead, teaching your baby a few basic signs like MILK, MORE, and UP can shift moment after moment, day after day, from crying to calm.

And one benefit many baby sign teachers don’t mention is the bonding and continued trust that happens when babies learn that their needs will get met consistently with simple signing moments. This creates an incredible confidence and calmness for both babies and parents. 

My Baby Signing 101 course is ready for you to watch in under an hour, with all the strategies & 10 simple signs so you can start signing together right away. $25 at link in bio.

What’s your POV today?
🎥: @marmyj

social_posts.post_text:
Your baby’s first attempts at a sign may not look exactly like the sign you’ve been showing them, but don’t worry. While their little hands may look different, know that they will gain finesse with practice and development, so make sure you confirm and support their efforts so they feel encouraged to keep signing.

Avoid trying to move their hands to “correct” their sign. Instead, cheer, confirm, and make sure they know they’re doing great! This will inspire them to keep signing for you. 🎉

Our job is to notice and respond. 👀

Baby Zylee’s mommy is signing HAT and cheering Zylee on as she pats her head, too. 

Think you are seeing a sign attempt? 

Yahoo! 🎉🎉🎉

Many babies first do a motion that looks like clapping for the sign MORE. 👏🏽

Nod your head, exclaim “Yes! Good job, I see you signing MORE, let’s have more! More!” And sign the correct sign for MORE back to them as you cheer them on.
💥💥💥💥💥💥 

(imagine if you were learning a new language or skill, wouldn’t you love to be championed and supported as you started? 🎉🎉)

▶️ Fact: many babies first sign MORE as a clapping motion, or with one hand tapping with their pointer finger to the other open palm. 👉🏽✋🏽
🎥: @innstapamm

social_posts.post_text:
FAQ: “How old should our baby be before we start using signs?”
(these slides got all mixed up, so I’ve written more info below)

The truth is -it’s not about your baby’s age, stage, or ability level. 

Language acquisition is achieved through shared, layered, repetitive exposure to language(s). 

Typically, babies learn to speak our verbal languages without us creating a ‘learning plan’ or deciding to ‘start’ at a certain time/age/stage. We just talk to them and repeat each day! 

Teaching sign language to little ones works the same way, and there is no timeline or perfect start time. 

Just get started if you feel ready! 💥

p.s. many parents give up signing when they don’t see response, and think their baby is too young or not getting it. 

Not true. 

I teach parents & caregivers exactly how to *successfully* share signs with babies and kids of all ages so it feels effortless and fun. 

Join my easy-to-follow classes that you can self-pace while watching from home, or grab a spot in my upcoming in-person classes @circusplaycafe & @kitsilanocc. 

💣Either way, you’ll see how incredibly simple and doable it is to start melting communication frustrations as a family no matter how old your baby.

➡️ Hit the link in bio to see more and not waste another moment. 

Your baby has so much to tell you!
------------------------

location.city_name: Signing Babies with Lee Ann Steyns

social_posts.post_text:
You may notice your little one moving their hands or wiggling their fingers… was that a sign⁉️

Often times it is! 

If you’ve been consistently showing a sign like MORE or MILK or ALL DONE and you notice your 6m+ baby holding their hands up and moving them, chances are they are making their first attempts at signing back. 

✋🏽🤚🏽 They may even just be looking down at their hands as they wiggle their fingers and marvel at the ability to move them! 

👣 These are (literally) the baby steps towards full independent movement with their hands. 

👏🏼 Bravo to both of you, by the way,  because while they are working out how to mimic and sign back the signs you’ve been showing them, it also means you’re paying attention to their attempts, which is imperative for sign language success. 

👀 When you notice those first attempts by baby to sign, make sure to support their efforts and cheer like crazy! 

“Yes! MORE, you want MORE! That’s great, let’s have MORE!”

Sign that sign correctly back as you gush and congratulate them, they’ll love it! Confirming their efforts to sign will also encourage them to keep trying, which will further progress their dexterity and development. 

In the beginning you may be unsure whether they really are signing or just working out how to move their hands. 

That’s okay! 

Make your best guess if it’s reasonable or possible, and go ahead and confirm what you think you saw… “MILK, yes, we’re having MILK, good job, MILK!”

By saying and signing the word correctly in context you’re still creating a positive signing moment for them. 

----------------------
👋🏻 Hi, I’m Lee Ann -mom of two, and expert baby signing instructor. I’ve been teaching baby signs + parenting for over 18 years and I’m still so passionate about both! social_posts.post_text:
“Is it time for MILK?”

💯

14m old Baby Lino just started signing MILK and this means Lino stays calm while getting dressed because he knows what’s next: MILK. 

No fussing, no screaming, no impatience at all. 

Just confidence and trust in the consistent communication approach that he’s seen a hundred times -> when my parents say & sign MILK, I get MILK next. 

This is the beauty of signing with our pre-verbal and non-verbal babies. 

Calm, confidence, and trust. 

If you find yourself frantically trying to dress the baby or quickly change their diaper as they scream for milk, you may want to start teaching this sign so they know what’s happening. 

Start by having their bottle ready, or where you’re going to nurse all set to go. Then say and sign MILK just as you start feeding. Then repeat this every day before feeds. Soon they’ll start recognizing the pattern and realizing what happens when you say & sign MILK. 

🌟🍼🌟

You’ve created a consistent pattern that will allow them (and you!) to stay calm and know what’s going on. 

⚡️ BAM!⚡️

Then keep adding signs so communication can grow and grow. 

❓What sign does your baby understand❓

➡️ If you want to see more of this kind of ease in your communication, my Baby Signing 101 course is ready for you to watch in under an hour, with all the strategies & 10 simple signs so you can start signing & having fun together right away. $25 at link in bio.
“Seriously everything we needed to start signing and it’s working! We love learning at our own pace and Fitz smiles and claps at the songs. I can’t thank you enough, Lee Ann!” -mama Tonia

#babysignlanguage #sleepandsign #cryitout

Too late to introduce myself? 😆

👋🏽 I’m Lee Ann and I teach baby sign language classes when I’m not co-wrangling two kids of my own. 

(they were my first @signingbabies because they came out busting to express themselves but could only cry and fuss to do it, and I was a mess).

I created my own curriculum to teach them ASL signs after being a full-time early childhood educator and learning ASL at university. 

It worked! The crying dialed right down and it was so rewarding to know what my babies wanted and be able to respond to them. 

The best part? 

They learned to sign enough to express themselves clearly before they could talk and I enjoyed parenthood so much more! 🔥

We’ve never looked back and I’ve been sharing my expertise with families ever since.

I’m also a geek about finding the perfect chocolate chip cookie recipe (seriously, please send yours if it’s crispy on the outside and chewy in the middle), watercolor painting, and #overlanding -my husband and I started camping in the wild in our jeep that he built out as a camper during covid and we’re hooked (see my saved stories).

So, follow along for signing tips and strategies that you can’t google -sign language is a physical language that babies can access way before talking, and utilize during those moments where words don’t work. 

I teach live classes virtually on the @kinedu app, and in-person in beautiful Vancouver, Canada. 

👋🏽 Nice to meet you❣️
(say hi and ask me any questions in the comments!)
__________________________________

social_posts.post_text:
Babies’ comprehension levels develop more quickly than their verbal speech. 

Often months faster. 

Which means they understand way more than we parents are usually aware of. 

Babies can learn to clap, point and wave bye-bye well before they can say the words. And no matter what their age, stage or ability, we can assume they cognitively understand more than it appears they do.

So we can be progressive and expose our babies to language -verbal and signs- early and often. 

Name the things they are interested in for maximum engagement (food, toys, pets, etc) and say the words out loud while signing them as you interact. 

But also name & sign your daily activities as you do them -up, down, diaper, bath, eat. 

Make your goal to present language constantly in your day. 

Repetition, context and exposure. 

BAM ⚡️

You’ll be keeping stride with your baby’s growing comprehension skills and creating a landscape for their language explosion. 

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

social_posts.post_text:
➡️ Comment “Happy Easter” and I’ll send you my printable song sheet with easy songs to make practice these signs with your cuties even more fun! 🎶 

Playful signs are super interesting to babies & toddlers (even though we parents often want to teach them more ‘practical’ signs) so try signing some light-hearted signs this spring! 

How to sign:

🪺EGG -in one smooth movement, tap one hand with index & middle finger extended from fist on top of the other hand that also has those two fingers extended. Move both hands down and out as if breaking apart an “egg.”

🐰 BUNNY RABBIT -with index & middle fingers of both hands extended and connected to each other, hold both fists stacked in front of your body, and bend fingers at the large knuckles twice to show a bunny’s ear’s flopping down.

🔍 SEARCH / HUNT -draw two circles in front of the face with a ‘C’ shaped hand, like you’re looking for something. 

🍴 EAT -move hand with fingers squished to your thumb towards your mouth, as if putting a morsel of food into your mouth.
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
👋🏻 Hi, I’m Lee Ann -mom of two, and expert baby signing instructor. I’ve been teaching baby signs + parenting for over 18 years and I know that making things easy & effective for everyone is the best way to reach success in signing as a family... it’s my super-power! 💪🏻

social_posts.post_text:
⭐️Expert tip: ⭐️ (save & share this!) 
Sign before you even start a change to signal what’s happening next. This will allow your little one to begin to see a pattern and expect what’s going to happen whenever they see you say and sign “DIAPER” or “CHANGE”. 

Example: “We’re all done with our lunch! Let’s CHANGE you and then we can go play with the toys. Time to CHANGE your diaper.” Then start that change. 

This also allows you to set solid patterns in your day around your activities by presenting them and doing them the same way each day. Babies and kids learn well with repetition and predictable patterns. 

(adults do, too!) 😉

➡️ If you’re not sure how to get started and want to see more ease in your communication, my Baby Signing 101 course is ready for you to watch in *under an hour* ⏰ with all the strategies & 10 simple signs so you can start signing together & having fun together right away. $25 at link in bio.

Less fussing, less guessing, more FUN!

“Seriously everything we needed to start signing and it’s working! We love learning at our own pace and Fitz smiles and claps at the songs. I can’t thank you enough, Lee Ann!” -mama Tonia

I’ve said this so many times, I see other baby sign language instructors now using this line, too, because it’s 💯 TRUE! 

⚡️⚡️It’s never too early nor too late to start teaching your baby to sign with you. ⚡️⚡️

If there are any gaps in their ability to express themselves successfully with you, then signs can help bridge that gap. 

Signs can replace crying and tantrums. 

Because crying won’t be necessary as you understand and respond to their signs. 

If you feel ready, your baby’s ready to follow your lead. They will absorb and learn signs with you at their own pace, and sign back when their little hands are ready!

👉🏽 Get my free guide for exactly HOW AND WHEN TO TEACH SIGNS TO YOUR LITTLE ONE with 3 perfect starter signs at my link in bio. 

Happy signing! 🫶🏼

social_posts.post_text:
This hack will work every time because you’re highlighting something your baby is already looking at and interested in, and we all learn better when we are engaged and motivated!

👋🏽 Hi, I’m Lee Ann -mom of two, and expert baby signing instructor. I’ve been teaching baby signs + parenting for over 18 years and as both an educator & parent, I know how to make things easy & effective for everyone to reach success in signing as a family... it’s my super-power! 

Something we need to do is take time to notice what our babies are looking at, then…

1️⃣ Stop and begin chatting about what you’re seeing: “Wow, look at all these big PUMPKINS! I see PUMPKINS. There are orange PUMPKINS and some white ones, too! So many PUMPKINS!” 

2️⃣ Sign PUMPKIN as you say it.
 
3️⃣ Smile and enjoy the moment! All the learning happens during play for babies 

➡️even if their face looks blank or you think they’re not following, trust they are taking in what you’re showing because they are!

4️⃣ Repeat every day!

The more often you model using signs in everyday life, the sooner your baby will understand and sign back to you when their hands are able. 

🎃HOW TO SIGN PUMPKIN:
Flick your middle finger onto the top of your other closed fist twice. 

SAVE and SHARE with your mama crew!
- - - - - - - - - - - - -

💯 Your baby has so much to tell you!

social_posts.post_text:
“We don’t want our baby watching screens”
 
This is a common response of families I meet, and I get it, because I didn’t want my baby girl watching screens either! 👶🏻

But because not all families can make it to my community baby signing classes or have access to classes in their own city, I record my virtual classes. 📍
 
I worked hard to figure out how to bring the magic of my award-winning in-person classes into a recorded class. 🎥💻
 
And it’s going great! 🎉
 
Families rate my virtual classes with 5/5 stars every time. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
 
If you’re worried about screen time, you can always watch the short videos yourself first, or place your phone, tablet, or laptop behind the baby while I lead you through songs and how to sign. 

❌ No screen time necessary!
 
And stay tuned, because I’m putting my virtual classes on sale for Black Friday... (I almost-never put these courses on sale, so make sure you’re on my mailing list at link in bio to receive the codes to save).

location.city_name: Signing Babies with Lee Ann Steyns

social_posts.post_text:
➡️ SAVE and SHARE with a parent that needs to hear this… ☺️
Even one or two signs can empower our babies in a profound way that would otherwise be unavailable before speech. 

At a certain point it becomes obvious that little ones are aware of their surroundings and know exactly what they want, like, and don’t like. And this typically happens around 4-6 months, waaaay before they can speak. 

So introducing a few signs allows our babies to express themselves and -this is the important part- be understood so fussing or crying isn’t necessary. 

BAM! 💥

It also sets up positive, respectful communication patterns that boost learning forever. 

It’s a win-win situation for everyone!

And again, just a few signs can be so helpful -words like (pick me) UP, (I want) MORE, and (We’re all) ALL DONE can be applied to so many situations with a baby. 

Have you noticed any moments when some successful signs could replace fussing? Are you ready to end the frustrations? 
_________________
👋🏻 Hi, I’m Lee Ann -mom of two, and expert baby signing instructor. I’ve been teaching baby signs + parenting for over 18 years and I’m still so passionate about both! And as an educator & parent, I know that making things easy & effective for everyone is the best way to reach success in signing as a family. It’s my super-power! 💪🏻

location.city_name: Signing Babies with Lee Ann Steyns

social_posts.post_text:
These 3 things are simple but essential to signing success. 

1. Don’t overwhelm yourself by trying to sign every activity and object you present to your baby. Pick one time in your day -maybe feeding or bath time -and show the pertinent sign as you begin. Keep things simple and slowly build more signs into your day as you feel ready. 

2️⃣ Observe your baby and notice what they get lit up about. Those are great conversation starters! And perfect moments for signing because your LO will be engaged and primed to learn. My son used to stop everything when he heard the garbage truck backing down our alley with a BEEP BEEP BEEP. So we’d go to the window and sign Truck. 

3️⃣ Decide to stick with signing. Thats it! Thats all you need to think about. Make the decision to use signs alongside your everyday verbal languages so your baby learns that this is how your family communicates. We speak and we sign. 

➡️ keep in mind that babies seldom respond visibly so don’t ever worry that they’re not learning with you. They’re soaking up all those signs even if you think they’re not looking at you or paying attention. 

📘 My brand new book ‘My First Baby Signs’ is a read-aloud story with easy-to-follow directions on how to sign 40 basic signs + tips for successful signing. 

“…this may be the strongest baby sign language board book I’ve ever encountered.” -Betsy Bird of the School Library Journal 

Get your copy $9.99 at link in bio ❣️

The most extraordinary thing about baby signing is that both parents AND babies experience amazing benefits. 

(honestly, I needed these benefits as a new mom to a shrieking, colicky baby that I felt desperate to understand and soothe. It was torture not understanding what was happening and how to help, and my pursuit to bond with my tiny girl is what started us on learning signs together).

Baby signing is an absolute game-changer for new parents, and there are tons more benefits!!
 
Scroll through and then tell us your fave thing about signing so more families can see the magic created with early communication. SHARE with another new family.

social_posts.post_text:
Here we go…! 
2️⃣0️⃣2️⃣4️⃣
Time for a new year and most of our thinking can lean towards making changes, but I’m focusing on acknowledging the things that are already going great. 

I want to confirm stuff I’m proud of and managed to learn or maintain in 2023. 

IT WAS A REALLY HARD YEAR. 

And I don’t want to just mentally wipe away all the residue to create some kind of “clean slate”. 

Instead, I’m carefully considering how to build on top of what’s been working. No need to start from scratch! 

So I’m going to bring back our “Sign of the Week” and “What’s that Sign?” segments in stories -the 2 most requested items from you! I let them slide this year and instead of starting a new feature, I’m going to commit to bringing them back. 

And I’ll make more reels showcasing YOUR signing babies! The cuteness speaks for itself and we’re all here for it. 

(you can dm me your cuties signing here!)

Personally, I managed to include 3-4 workouts in my week most weeks in 2023. I’m so proud of myself for scheduling them in and I feel better in my body and my mind. I’m going to build on that and add 1 more weight training. 

❓ What are you doubling down on in 2024❓

Take a minute to identify something you rocked this year. We are so quick to note the misses, but let’s go into 2024 building on the wins!! 💪🏼
 
Resist being humble or shy. Ignore that voice in your head telling you to do better/more/different. 

You are amazing and I know you did some great things! ⭐️⭐️⭐️

📘Author 👩🏻‍🦱Mom 🤟🏽Expert Instructor
